journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine

title-group.article-title: Biomechanical analysis of rheumatoid arthritis of the wrist joint

article-meta.aff: 1Medical Implant Technology Group, Faculty of Health Science and Biomedical Engineering, Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, Malaysia
2Orthopaedic Department, Hospital Universiti Sains Malaysia, Malaysia
3Department of Applied Mechanics, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, Malaysia

author-notes.corresp: Mohammed Rafiq Abdul Kadir, Medical Implant Technology Group, Faculty of Health Science and Biomedical Engineering, Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, 81310, UTM Skudai, Johor, Malaysia. Email: rafiq@biomedical.utm.my

abstract.p: The wrist is the most complex joint for virtual three-dimensional simulations, and the complexity is even more pronounced when dealing with skeletal disorders of the joint such, as rheumatoid arthritis (RA). In order to analyse the biomechanical difference between healthy and diseased joints, three-dimensional models of these two wrist conditions were developed from computed tomography images. These images consist of eight carpal bones, five metacarpal bones, the distal radius and ulna. The cartilages were developed based on the shape of the available articulations and ligaments were simulated via mechanical links. The RA model was developed accurately by simulating all ten common criteria of the disease related to the wrist. Results from the finite element (FE) analyses showed that the RA model produced three times higher contact pressure at the articulations compared to the healthy model. Normal physiological load transfer also changed from predominantly through the radial side to an increased load transfer approximately 5% towards the ulnar. Based on an extensive literature search, this is the first ever reported work that simulates the pathological conditions of the rheumatoid arthritis of the wrist joint.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The wrist joint is involved in virtually every human functional activity and, as such, is exposed to high number of traumatic injuries, primary osteoarthritis and secondary degenerative disease.1 One of the most common skeletal diseases that is always associated with the wrist joint is rheumatoid arthritis (RA).2 Even though other joints such as the hip and knee can also be affected by RA, the most commonly affected joint is the wrist.3

In general, there are three main symptoms of the wrist affected by RA: cartilage destruction, synovial proliferation and ligamentous laxity.3 Damage to the cartilage, such as thinning, occurred due to cytochemical effects resulting in degradation and inhibition of new cartilage.4 Bone erosion due to the synovial proliferation may cause sharp bony edges which might lead to tendon rupture.3 The laxity of the ligaments caused by the synovial expansion will result in altered physiological bone translation and displacement.5 Occurring concurrently, these changes will lead to biomechanical imbalances that ultimately result in visible deformity of the wrist.6

Understanding the pathomechanics and the possible course of RA is important as cases tend to be patient specific.3 This can be deduced from previous clinical studies where treatment for severe RA, such as total wrist arthroplasty, was not as successful as replacements for other joints such as the hip and knee.6 One of the reasons for this is the difficulty of thoroughly analysing the behaviour of the disease due to its complexity.7 Simulating such a complex system is extremely challenging and thus has received little attention. A detailed insight of the arthritic wrist and its associated cause could be explored through biomechanical three-dimensional finite element (FE) analyses. These techniques have been widely used to analyse load transmission on relatively less complex human joints such as the hip and knee,8,9 and has been accepted by medical researchers as one of the important assistive tools in surgical planning.10–13 Even though this method has been used for simulation of various human joints, the amount of literature related to the wrist is fairly limited with most reports on the three-dimensional model development.11, 14–18

This study aimed to investigate the biomechanical behaviour of a rheumatic wrist using FE analysis, with a healthy wrist model used as a control. A simulation of such a complex system was performed using ten major characteristics of Type IIIa RA wrist: a pathological type suitable for arthroplasty. Load transmission and contact pressure at the articulations are important issues to address where results were compared with other clinical and numerical published reports. This study provides further insights into the complex biomechanical behaviour of the diseased wrist through computer simulation which could be useful for the development of implants to replace type IIIa RA wrist.

sec.title: Geometry
sec.p: A three-dimensional (3D) model of the wrist joint was reconstructed from computed tomography (CT) images of a healthy asymptomatic male (53 year old volunteer) with no radiological signs of pathology. The scans were taken from the whole upper limb of a healthy human body in extended (33.11°) and deviated (17.34° ulnar) wrist position, measured relative to anatomically based radial coordinate system.19 The radiograph images of the wrist, ranging from the distal end of the long bones of the left forearm (radius and ulna) to the proximal third of the metacarpals, were then cropped. The total length of the scans was 102.3 mm with a resolution of 0.98 mm in plane and the slice thickness was 1.5 mm. Semi-automatic segmentation was performed using Mimics software (Materialise, Belgium) on each CT image to select the cortical region. The inner surface of this region was then used as the outer layer for the cancellous bone. The 3D models of the wrist were constructed using AMIRA software (Mercury Computer Systems, Inc., San Diego, USA) where an automatic compilation through the software’s marching cubes algorithm was applied, which generates a 3D triangular surface mesh. The ratio of twice the radius of the inscribed circle to the radius of the ascribed circle of the triangle was used as the normalised indicator to determine the mesh quality.20 The value was set at 0.4 to produce a high quality of surface mesh.17 Additionally, an average element size of 0.4 mm was chosen which resulted in an accurate geometric description of the bone geometry which has been compared and considered acceptable according to an anatomy software.21 Boolean operations were performed in order to check for any intersecting bodies. Marc.Mentat (MSC.Software, Santa Ana, USA) software was used to convert the completed model to 3D solid linear first-order tetrahedral elements. This resulted in a FE model of the healthy wrist consisting of 828,888 elements and 204,218 nodes.

Cartilage layers in the articulations between the solid geometry were modelled by manually identifying the articulating surfaces between bones. In order to form the cartilage, extracted profiles representing the cartilage distribution surfaces were extruded with a thickness size of half the minimum distance between two bones,14 resulting in a good geometrical representation and material distribution of the cartilage (Figure 1). The distribution of the cartilage was compared and considered acceptable according to anatomy software.21

caption.p: Finite element model of the healthy wrist showing the cartilage as extruded elements at the articulations between bones and ligament as a set of mechanical links.

sec.p: All 60 ligaments were modelled using linear mechanical links, and the positions of their insertion points were estimated based on an anatomy software21 and a previously published anatomical study.22 The stiffness of the ligaments was varied from 40 to 350 N/mm based on various published experimental works14,18,23–25 as shown in Table 1. For ligaments where their material properties could not be found in the literature, the properties of the neighbouring ligaments would be used.15 Parallel multiple links were applied and the number varied according to the distribution of the origin and insertion of the ligaments.

caption.p: A list of modelled ligaments specifying their connections and defined stiffness parameters.

sec.title: Modelling of the wrist affected by rheumatoid arthritis
sec.p: Based on past literatures, Type IIIa (disintegration type with more ligamentous instability) of the RA wrist, in which ten characteristics were included in the FE modelling

list-item.p: Loss of carpal height due to bone destruction.2 The simulation was performed according to the carpometacarpal ratio of 0.4 representing severe rheumatic wrist (Figure 2, section 2).26
Dislocation of the carpus in the ulnar direction because of a loss of tension of the radiotriquetral ligament, irrespective of the status of the ulnar head (Figure 2, section 3).2
Dislocation of the proximal carpal row in the palmar and ulnar direction (Figure 2, section 4).2
Scapholunar dissociation (SLD) with scapholunate advanced collapse wrist arthritis (SLAC) stage 2 (Figure 2, section 5).2
Dislocation of the scaphoid in the palmar direction due to the radial insertion of the Testut ligament synovialitis (Figure 2, section 6).2

Hand scoliosis due to ruptured tendon. This mechanism ends in a changed axis of the wrist to the ulna with a consecutive rotation of the metacarpal bones in the radial direction (Figure 2, section 7).2
Reduction of contact between the lunate and radius (Figure 2, section 8).2
Osteoporotic bone.2,27 This criterion was simulated by reducing the elastic modulus of the bones: 33% for the cortical bone and 66% for the cancellous bone.28

caption.p: Finite element model of the wrist joint affected by RA together with steps to simulate the first to ninth characteristics.

sec.p: The simulated RA wrist was then converted into solid tetrahedral mesh which produced an FE model consisting of 1,115,599 elements and 233,570 nodes. Steps to simulate the first to the ninth characteristics together with the applied boundary condition are illustrated in Figure 2.

sec.title: Contact modelling
sec.p: A deformable-to-deformable contact was established between the articulating surfaces. For the healthy model, a small value (0.02) of friction coefficient was used to approximate frictionless contact.17 The RA model, on the other hand, was assigned with an assumed friction coefficient of 0.3 due to the relatively rougher surface of the contacted bones.29

sec.title: Tissue properties modelling
sec.p: The bone parts of the wrist were modelled using isotropic, linear elastic material definition representing the cortical bone (healthy model: E = 18 GPa, ν = 0.2 and RA model: E = 12 GPa, ν = 0.2) and cancellous bone (healthy model: E = 100 MPa, ν = 0.25 and RA model: E = 33 MPa, ν = 0.25).17 The large deformation behaviour of the cartilage in the healthy model was simulated using hyper-elastic material properties,30 using the Mooney-Rivlin parameters of C01 = 0.41 MPa and C10 = 4.1 MPa.31

sec.title: Simulations
sec.p: The load simulating the static gripping force of the wrist calculated by Gislason et al. (2009)15 was used in this study. The magnitude of the resultant compression pressure was 7.33 MPa distributed over the five metacarpals. All the applied loads and the distribution of the loading are presented in Figure 3.

caption.p: Applied compressive pressure for each metacarpal (a), together with the boundary condition setting for the healthy (b), and RA (c) model simulating static hand grip action.

sec.p: In order to assist convergence of the solution, the proximal ends of the radius and ulna are fully constrained.17 The carpometacarpal joint and the insertion of the tendons (abductor pollicis longus muscle, flexor carpi radialis muscle, flexor carpi ulnaris muscle, extensor carpi ulnaris muscle, extensor carpi radialis brevis muscle, extensor carpi radialis longus muscle) were fixed prohibiting motion in the x and y direction, to enable movements of all bones (excluding the proximal ends of the radius and ulna) in the direction of the applied loading.18 All these settings worked as input of the FE analyses using Marc. Mentat (MSC.Software, Santa Ana, CA) software.

sec.title: Bone stress distribution
sec.p: Figure 4 shows the von Mises stress distribution for the palmar aspect of the healthy and RA models with a histogram showing their average stresses. Most of the stresses were concentrated at the cortical radius with an average value of 4.1 MPa for both the RA and healthy model. However, the cancellous bone in both models showed the lowest magnitudes of 0.04 MPa and 0.01 MPa, respectively. For the carpal bones, the RA model showed different stress distribution compared to the healthy model. The RA model had the highest average stress value at the trapezoid (4.1 MPa), whilst for the healthy model the trapezium had the highest average stress value (5.3 MPa). High stress concentration (63% for the healthy and 58% for the RA model) was also found at the radial side of the joint, as clearly depicted in Figure 4. Load transmission at the radiocarpal joint showed a transfer of 63% and 64% of the load to the scaphoid of the healthy and RA model, respectively. On average, the osteoporotic RA bones had 20% lower stresses generated compared to the healthy bones.

caption.p: Von Mises stress distribution for the palmar aspect of the healthy model (a), the RA model (b), and a histogram showing the average stress in each bone (c).

sec.p: Analyses at the diaphysis of the distal radius showed that the strain value of cartilage on the healthy model were on average ε = 1.40%. The corresponding value for the cortical bone was ε = 0.02% for the healthy model and ε = 0.06% for the RA model. The cancellous bone for the healthy and RA model had relatively higher strain values of ε = 0.17% and ε = 0.15%, respectively.

The load transfer behaviour at the capitolunate and capitoscaphoid articulation was also analysed (Figures 5a and 5b). The results showed high stress concentration at the dorsal radial portion of distal lunate for the RA model (maximum 49 MPa), whilst the healthy model showed a more well distributed load transfer (maximum 18 MPa).

caption.p: The posterior view of the load distribution at the capitolunate and capitoscaphoid articulation showing the distribution of load transfer for the healthy model (a), compared to the RA model (b). The line chart (c) shows the total contact pressure at each bone.

sec.title: Contact parameter
sec.p: In both models, it was observed that the values of maximum contact pressure for selected articulations decreased gradually from the radial towards the ulnar side of the wrist joint (Table 2). The maximum value of contact pressure was found at different articulations in both cases: MC1-trapezium for the healthy model with 150 MPa, and at the lunate-radius for the RA model with a value of 160 MPa. The minimum corresponding values were also found at different articulations, however, both were located at the ulnar side; at the hamate-triquetrium (0.03 MPa) in the healthy model, and MC4-hamate (8.9 MPa) in the RA model. The overall plot of contact pressures showed that the RA model had three times higher contact pressure compared to the healthy model (Figure 5c). Higher contact pressure was generated at the carpal bones in both models with a value of 65% compared to the metacarpals and the forearm bones.

caption.p: The average contact pressure at the articulations of selected joints.

sec.p: Investigation of the contact pressure was made at the radiocarpal joint as this is arguably the most critical articulation in the wrist joint (Figure 6).15,32 The magnitude and distribution of pressure was different in both models, in which a well distributed with low contact pressure (maximum 21 MPa at the radioscaphoid articulation) was observed in the healthy model. The RA model, on the other hand, has an uneven pressure distribution with higher contact pressure (maximum 116 MPa at the radiolunate articulation) concentrated at the sharp edges on the bone surface.

caption.p: The superior view of radioscapholunate joint showing the contact pressure plot of the healthy (a), and RA (b) model. It can be seen that the radioscaphoid facet was elliptical in shape whilst the radiolunate facet was circular in shape.

sec.title: Comparative analysis
sec.p: Comparison was made between the results from this study and other published numerical and experimental work by others.15,17,33–35 Slight differences were observed due to variations in anatomical configuration especially in cadaveric studies.34 Nonetheless, several general agreements were found from these cadaveric and simulation studies. An assessment made on the model quality based on surface element confirming its reliability where the ratio of twice the radius of the inscribed circle to the radius of the ascribed circle of the triangle for 90% of elements was greater than 0.80 (where unity represents an equilateral triangle).

Only the healthy wrist model in this study was compared since there is no reported literature on the RA model that is suitable for direct comparison. Several aspects of stress transfer emphasized in previous studies were in agreement with our study. One of them is the load transmission at the radiocarpal joint which was transferred more to the scaphoid than the lunate.33

In their cadaveric studies, Macleod et al. (2007)34 reported that 68% of the load at the forearm was transferred through the radius, whilst Gislason et al. (2009)15 reported a range between 78.7% to 92.8% in their simulation studies. The two reported studies showed the importance of the radius as the most significant load bearer in the wrist joint. Most of the load for the healthy wrist joint found in this study was transferred radially similar to those reported by Gislason et al. (2010)17 and Givissis et al. (2009).35

The strain magnitudes at the radius were also compared with previous clinical reports. Bosisio et al. (2007)36 reported an ultimate strain value for the cortical radius to be εu = 1.50% and the yield strain of εy = 0.90%. Another study by Kerin at al. (1998)37 reported a failure strain value of cartilage under compression to be 30%. The strain values from our simulation were below the failure criteria as mentioned by the previous researchers.

sec.title: Biomechanical effect of symptoms and pathophysiology criteria
sec.p: The deterioration in mechanical properties of the associated tissues and physiological function of the wrist affected by RA2 was prescribed and thus simulate to a certain extent the non-physiological behaviour of the rheumatic wrist. Although ten characteristics were analysed as a whole, the biomechanical behaviour will be discussed separately to ease understanding of such a complex condition.

The osteoporotic RA bones analysed here had 20% lower stresses generated compared to the healthy bones thus indicating less stiffness of the RA bones. Patients suffering from RA tend to underutilize the affected joint due to pain especially for severe cases. Hence, this situation leads to slow generation of the bone cell resulting in bone loss or bone atrophy.38 The continued loss of bone substance or volume could further worsen the osteoporotic condition of the bone.

The mechanism of RA started with destruction of the soft tissues.3 Simulated in this project was the deterioration of the articular cartilage. The simulation of cartilage damage due to chondrolysis2 was found to contribute to drastic changes in the mechanical properties of the articulation of the joint. This finding was also supported by Carrigan et al. (2003)18 where the material properties of the cartilage had the largest effect on contact pressures at the cartilage surfaces and on compressive stresses within the cartilage layers. In this FE analysis, the cartilages were modelled using hyper-elastic properties to allow large deformation cartilage behaviour. This property functions as a nearly frictionless bearing while uniformly transferring loads on underlying bone preventing high stress concentrations.39 Therefore, the absence of the cartilages resulted in higher stress concentration with high contact pressure generated at the articulation areas. The analysed contact pressure showed that the absence of the cartilage in the RA model resulted in three times higher contact pressure compared to the healthy model (Figure 5c).

The high contact pressure was also due to the eroded surfaces of bones with the existence of sharp edges, which can be clearly seen in the RA model (Figure 6b). The healthy model, on the other hand, showed a good distribution of stress. These differences occured due to the absence of the cartilage as well as the existence of the sharp edges in the RA model.

In RA, inflammation of the synovial fluid could severely affect the ligaments through stretching or tearing with a potential eventual deformity.2 This condition distorts the constraint initially provided by the ligaments and led to the random translation, dislocation, and rotation of the affected bones. This resulted in the dislocation of carpus towards ulnar causing changes in load distribution, where higher load was transmitted through the ulnar side in the RA model (42%) compared to the healthy model (37%). The differences were also due to the hand scoliosis condition, in which the radially rotated metacarpals as prescribed in this study caused the direction of the stresses to move towards the ulnar side. This is due to the highest stress at the first metacarpal located at the lateral side of the wrist joint pushed the bones towards the ulnar.

The higher load transfer to the ulnar side was also due to stage 2 of scapholunate advance collapse (SLAC) with scapholunate dissociation (SLD) (Figures 5a and 5b). For the healthy wrist, the contact between the capitate, scaphoid and lunate was considerably uniform, resulting in normal load bearing. However, the RA model had a complete destruction of the radioscaphoid joint with collapse of the articular space due to the weakened and distorted scapholunate ligaments resulting in subluxation of the scaphoid.40 The simulated collapse had clearly illustrated that the capitolunate joint was unable to physiologically sustain the applied load. The abnormal load transfer due to this condition was clearly depicted in our RA model showing high stress concentration at the capitolunate articulation compared to the scapholunate. The capitate no longer has equivalent support at both the scaphoid and lunate, dislocating the dorsal radial portion of distal lunate articular surface causing injury to the cartilage at the capitolunate joint.

The SLAC and SLD also caused some other physiological abnormalities.40 The scaphoid is at risk of degenerative changes due to the nature of the articulation. The scaphoid facet is elleptical in shape whilst the articulation of the lunate with the radius is spherical (Figure 6). Therefore, any changes to the position of the scaphoid will result in incongruent loading of the radioscaphoid facet.40 Our study is the first ever reported literature where both SLD (through separation of the scaphoid and lunate) and SLAC (through rotary subluxation of the scaphoid) were incorporated to simulate the worst case of RA. One of the major differences for SLAC compared to the healthy wrist was the reduction of the contact area between radius and scaphoid, resulting in the increased load surrounding the area.40 Our study predicted a similar outcome where the average contact pressure at the radioscaphoid joint for the RA model was higher than the healthy model.

Despite all the findings reported in this study, the wrist is a very complex joint and patient specific, with the complexity even more pronounced when simulating pathological conditions such as RA. There are various limitations to our study and there was a certain level of uncertainty involved in simulating the RA wrist. Even though we have simulated all of the ten characteristics, quantitative data for each one is scarce. The only quantitative data that we found was the carpometacarpal ratio of 0.4 for severe RA. This ratio provided the upper and lower boundary of the carpal region. The position of the individual bones has to be determined from clinical reports; for example, the proximal carpal row has to be dislocated in the palmar and ulnar direction. For the FE model itself, there were numerous assumptions that need to be analysed such as linearity–non linearity, isotropic–orthotropic, second-order element–first-order element, tetrahedrals–hexahedrals, touching contact–glue contact, effect of sharp gradient between the two material properties, to name a few. As the amount of time required to analyse all these uncertainties was too prohibitive, we have decided to use existing data reported from the literature. The enormous amounts of data for this kind of sensitivity analyses study will be conducted in the future. Nevertheless, this is by far the first ever attempt at creating a working model to analyse complications related to the wrist and can be used to gather information for a potential solution.

It can be concluded that this biomechanical study of the rheumatic wrist had successfully identified that damage of soft and hard tissues caused altered biomechanical behaviour of the joint. Abnormal stress distribution and contact pressure at the articulation was found for the RA model.

ack.p: The authors wish to thank Mohd Yazid Yahya from the Centre for Composites, Universiti Teknologi Malaysia and Tengku Kamarul Zaman Tengku Zainal Abidin from the Department of Orthopaedics, Universiti Malaya for their valuable comments and support.
